message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has multiple polyps, which are a key feature of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), an inherited disorder caused by a mutation in the APC gene on chromosome 5.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and family history suggest familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which is caused by a mutation on chromosome 5. Polyps are common in patients with FAP and the risk of developing colon cancer is high.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of hundreds of small polyps in the colon and the family history of colon cancer suggest the possibility of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). FAP is caused by a mutation of the APC tumor suppressor gene located on chromosome 5. Thus, the correct answer is (A).

The presentation of hundreds of small polyps in the colon in a 14-year-old boy with a positive family history is suggestive of Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). FAP is caused by a mutation of the APC gene on chromosome 5. Therefore, the answer is (A).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of hundreds of small polyps in the colon suggests a diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which is caused by a mutation on chromosome 5. Option B is incorrect because mutations on chromosome 7 are associated with cystic fibrosis. Option C is incorrect because mutations on chromosome 17 are associated with neurofibromatosis and BRCA1/BRCA2 mutations. Option D is incorrect because X-linked mutations are associated with diseases such as hemophilia and Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of hundreds of polyps in the colon suggests Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP), which is caused by a mutation in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene on chromosome 5. Other forms of inherited colon cancer syndromes may have fewer or different types of polyps.
